elements.content: Fumaric sodium (Na2fum) reacts with CoCl2·6H2O to form a one-dimensional (1D) coordination polymeric structure {[Co(bpp)2(H2O)2]·fum·8H2O} n (1) in the presence of 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane (bpp) from water at room temperature. An unprecedented two-dimensional (6,3) net topology of hydrogen-bonded water layers results from free water molecules through templating with fum. The 1D polymeric chains behave as pillars to join these water sheets to make an overall three-dimensional supramolecular architecture by hydrogen-bonding interactions.
elements.clean_text: Fumaric sodium (Na2fum) reacts with CoCl2⋅6H2O to form a one-dimensional (1D) coordination polymeric structure {[Co(bpp)2(H2O)2]⋅fum⋅8H2O} n  (1) in the presence of 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane (bpp) from water at room temperature. An unprecedented two-dimensional (6,3) net topology of hydrogen-bonded water layers results from free water molecules through templating with fum. The 1D polymeric chains behave as pillars to join these water sheets to make an overall three-dimensional supramolecular architecture by hydrogen-bonding interactions.

elements.content: Fumaric sodium (Na2fum) reacts with CoCl2·6H2O to form a one-dimensional (1D) coordination polymeric structure {[Co(bpp)2(H2O)2]·fum·8H2O} n (1) in the presence of 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane (bpp) from water at room temperature. An unprecedented two-dimensional (6,3) net topology of hydrogen-bonded water layers results from free water molecules through templating with fum. The 1D polymeric chains behave as pillars to join these water sheets to make an overall three-dimensional supramolecular architecture by hydrogen-bonding interactions.
elements.clean_text: Fumaric sodium (Na2fum) reacts with CoCl2⋅6H2O to form a one-dimensional (1D) coordination polymeric structure {[Co(bpp)2(H2O)2]⋅fum⋅8H2O} n  (1) in the presence of 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane (bpp) from water at room temperature. An unprecedented two-dimensional (6,3) net topology of hydrogen-bonded water layers results from free water molecules through templating with fum. The 1D polymeric chains behave as pillars to join these water sheets to make an overall three-dimensional supramolecular architecture by hydrogen-bonding interactions.

elements.content: Hydrogen-bonding interactions, their fluctuations, and their rearrangement dynamics determine the properties of liquid water, some of which are considered anomalous. A major obstacle to fully understand its behavior is a correct description of the cooperative nature of hydrogen-bonding interactions among a collection of water molecules. This diversity of hydrogen-bonding interactions is very important in the biological field as it can enforce a delicate balance among several possible conformations of enzymes essential for their functions. The key to testing and calibrating theoretical studies to comprehend this liquid is having precise structural data of hydrogen-bonded small water clusters in diverse environments. The advantage of clusters is the possibility to simply vary the size and to investigate the development of properties of the condensed phase in a step-by-step manner. This realization has led to an upsurge in studying small water clusters in different environments. An understanding of the properties of water is important from the perspectives of protein crystallization, stabilization and functioning of biomolecules, cloud and ice formation, solution chemistry, and so on.
elements.clean_text: Hydrogen-bonding interactions, their fluctuations, and their rearrangement dynamics determine the properties of liquid water, some of which are considered anomalous. A major obstacle to fully understand its behavior is a correct description of the cooperative nature of hydrogen-bonding interactions among a collection of water molecules. This diversity of hydrogen-bonding interactions is very important in the biological field as it can enforce a delicate balance among several possible conformations of enzymes essential for their functions. The key to testing and calibrating theoretical studies to comprehend this liquid is having precise structural data of hydrogen-bonded small water clusters in diverse environments. The advantage of clusters is the possibility to simply vary the size and to investigate the development of properties of the condensed phase in a step-by-step manner. This realization has led to an upsurge in studying small water clusters in different environments. An understanding of the properties of water is important from the perspectives of protein crystallization, stabilization and functioning of biomolecules, cloud and ice formation, solution chemistry, and so on.

elements.content: Attention has also been paid to the infinite one- and two-dimensional (1D and 2D) water morphologies, which structurally lie between small water clusters and bulk water/ice. Recent studies have focused on the morphologies of water clusters in diverse chemical environments to provide quantitative characterization of the hydrogen-bonded networks in liquid water or ice. Some individual examples of 2D water morphologies containing uniform (H2O)6, (H2O)8, (H2O)12, and (H2O)18 rings have been described to have structural similarity to water or ice, although liquid water should contain different small water culstrers. The formation of different 2D water morphologies may be due to a small change in the shape or distribution of the hydrophilic groups on the host networks. Therefore, a systematic variation of these backbones and determination of the corresponding water layers will improve our understanding of the structures of water.
elements.clean_text: Attention has also been paid to the infinite one- and two-dimensional (1D and 2D) water morphologies, which structurally lie between small water clusters and bulk water/ice. Recent studies have focused on the morphologies of water clusters in diverse chemical environments to provide quantitative characterization of the hydrogen-bonded networks in liquid water or ice. Some individual examples of 2D water morphologies containing uniform (H2O)6, (H2O)8, (H2O)12, and (H2O)18 rings have been described to have structural similarity to water or ice, although liquid water should contain different small water culstrers. The formation of different 2D water morphologies may be due to a small change in the shape or distribution of the hydrophilic groups on the host networks. Therefore, a systematic variation of these backbones and determination of the corresponding water layers will improve our understanding of the structures of water.

elements.content: In general, the incorporation of water clusters or networks into polymeric architectures is accomplished using synthons that are rich in hydrogen-bond donor/acceptor groups, with inter- and intramolecular hydrogen bonding and other noncovalent interactions being the main driving forces for the assembly of such systems. The fum dianion contains two carboxylate groups that can be harnessed in hydrogen-bonding networks, and it can also serve as a template in the formation of hydrogen-bond-driven polymeric systems. Herein, we describe (H2O)18-containing 2D supramolecular water sheets by using fum as a template, and 1D polymeric chains acting as pillars to join these water sheets to form a stable three-dimensional (3D) framework.
elements.clean_text: In general, the incorporation of water clusters or networks into polymeric architectures is accomplished using synthons that are rich in hydrogen-bond donor/acceptor groups, with inter- and intramolecular hydrogen bonding and other noncovalent interactions being the main driving forces for the assembly of such systems. The fum dianion contains two carboxylate groups that can be harnessed in hydrogen-bonding networks, and it can also serve as a template in the formation of hydrogen-bond-driven polymeric systems. Herein, we describe (H2O)18-containing 2D supramolecular water sheets by using fum as a template, and 1D polymeric chains acting as pillars to join these water sheets to form a stable three-dimensional (3D) framework.

elements.content: Compound 1 was prepared by reacting CoCl2·6H2O, bpp, H2fum, and NaOH in water as pink crystals in 68% yield and characterized by X-ray crystallography, elemental analysis, and vibrational spectroscopy.
elements.clean_text: Compound 1 was prepared by reacting CoCl2⋅6H2O, bpp, H2fum, and NaOH in water as pink crystals in 68% yield and characterized by X-ray crystallography, elemental analysis, and vibrational spectroscopy.

elements.content: Complex 1 contains one [Co(bpp)2(H2O)2]2+ cation, one fumaric dianion, and eight lattice water molecules (Figure a). The metal−organic framework consists of 1D chains (Figure b) formed by interconnecting ring structures made from two bpp units, two Co2+ ions, and two water molecules. Each cobalt ion is six-coordinate, having octahedral geometry with equatorial coordination from four nitrogen atoms from four different bpp ligands, and two water molecules occupy the axial sites.
elements.clean_text: Complex 1 contains one [Co(bpp)2(H2O)2]2+ cation, one fumaric dianion, and eight lattice water molecules (Figure a). The metal-organic framework consists of 1D chains (Figure b) formed by interconnecting ring structures made from two bpp units, two Co2+ ions, and two water molecules. Each cobalt ion is six-coordinate, having octahedral geometry with equatorial coordination from four nitrogen atoms from four different bpp ligands, and two water molecules occupy the axial sites.

elements.content: (a) ORTEP representation (30% thermal probability ellipsoids) of the crystal structure of1; H atoms and the lattice water molecular have been omitted for clarity. (b) Perspective view of the 1D structure of 1.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) ORTEP representation (30% thermal probability ellipsoids) of the crystal structure of1; H atoms and the lattice water molecular have been omitted for clarity. (b) Perspective view of the 1D structure of 1.

elements.content: Interestingly, an ordered 2D hydrogen-bonded water layer with a (6,3) topology is observed in the bc-plane (Figure ). Hydrogen-bonding association generates a 18-membered centrosymmetric water ring (Figure ) consisting of four O4w, four O5w, four O6w, and six O7w centers. These 18-membered rings are fused together to form a 2D supramolecular (H2O)18 morphology with a corrugated sheet. A closer view of the (H2O)18 rings illustrates that each water monomer acts as both hydrogen-bond donor and hydrogen-bond acceptor. The average O···O separation of 2.761 Å in the supromolecular (H2O)18 morphology is very close to the corresponding value of 2.759 Å in ice I h. In contrast to the recently observed 2D supramolecular (H2O)18 morphology, which is structurally similar to liquid water, the O···O separation in our (H2O)18 morphology is structurally similar to ice I h. The O···O···O angles range from 102.14 to 139.83°, considerably deviating from the preferred ideal tetrahedral geometry of water.
elements.clean_text: Interestingly, an ordered 2D hydrogen-bonded water layer with a (6,3) topology is observed in the bc-plane (Figure ). Hydrogen-bonding association generates a 18-membered centrosymmetric water ring (Figure ) consisting of four O4w, four O5w, four O6w, and six O7w centers. These 18-membered rings are fused together to form a 2D supramolecular (H2O)18 morphology with a corrugated sheet. A closer view of the (H2O)18 rings illustrates that each water monomer acts as both hydrogen-bond donor and hydrogen-bond acceptor. The average O⋅⋅⋅O separation of 2.761 Å in the supromolecular (H2O)18 morphology is very close to the corresponding value of 2.759 Å in ice I h. In contrast to the recently observed 2D supramolecular (H2O)18 morphology, which is structurally similar to liquid water, the O⋅⋅⋅O separation in our (H2O)18 morphology is structurally similar to ice I h. The O⋅⋅⋅O⋅⋅⋅O angles  range from 102.14 to 139.83°, considerably deviating from the preferred ideal tetrahedral geometry of water.

elements.content: Perspective view of supramolecular (H2O)18 morphology in 1.
elements.clean_text: 3  Perspective view of supramolecular (H2O)18 morphology in 1.

elements.content: It is worth noting that the formation of the (H2O)18 water ring adopts a template technique. The fum exists in the center of each 18-membered water ring steadily (Figure ). Within the water layer, the individual (H2O)18 water ring is hydrogen bonded to four oxygen atoms from fum (O···O:  2.667, 2.823, 2.786, and 2.823 Å) (Figure ). Moreover, the 2D supramolecular sheets are supported by 1D polymeric pillars to form an infinite 3D framework (Figure ). The coordinated water molecules play a crucial role in the formation of the 3D supramolecular architecture. Two kinds of significant hydrogen bonds are formed between each coordinated water molecule and 2D water layer, with the former providing hydrogen-bond donors and the latter serving as hydrogen-bond acceptors (one oxygen atom of one free water and one oxygen atom of one fum). It is obvious that the 2D (H2O)18 morphology is found in metal−organic framework {[Co(bpp)2(H2O)2]·fum·8H2O} n , which is not similar to the recently reported one trapped in a phosphorus functionalized trimeric amino acid host.
elements.clean_text: It is worth noting that the formation of the (H2O)18 water ring adopts a template technique. The fum exists in the center of each 18-membered water ring steadily (Figure ). Within the water layer, the individual (H2O)18 water ring is hydrogen bonded to four oxygen atoms from fum (O⋅⋅⋅O: 2.667, 2.823, 2.786, and 2.823 Å) (Figure ). Moreover, the 2D supramolecular sheets are supported by 1D polymeric pillars to form an infinite 3D framework (Figure ). The coordinated water molecules play a crucial role in the formation of the 3D supramolecular architecture. Two kinds of significant hydrogen bonds are formed between each coordinated water molecule and 2D water layer, with the former providing hydrogen-bond donors and the latter serving as hydrogen-bond acceptors (one oxygen atom of one free water and one oxygen atom of one fum). It is obvious that the 2D (H2O)18 morphology is found in metal-organic framework {[Co(bpp)2(H2O)2]⋅fum⋅8H2O} n , which is not similar to the recently reported one trapped in a phosphorus functionalized trimeric amino acid host.

elements.content: A perspective view showing how water layers and 1D polymeric chains form the 3D framework.

elements.content: Thermal gravimetric analysis on a 10.02 mg sample of 1 shows the onset of water loss at 50 °C. Water removal takes place without showing any distinct plateau in the curve, giving a total loss of 20.8% at ∼150 °C corresponding to loss of free water molecules (calculated value, 19.2%). The complete decomposition of the compound is achieved above 180 °C. The FTIR spectrum of 1 shows a broad band centered around 3202 cm-1, which vanishes on heating the compound under vacuum at 140 °C for 2 h due to the escape of water from the lattice. Deliberate exposure to water vapor for 3 days does not lead to reabsorption of water into the lattice as monitored by FTIR spectroscopy. The O−H stretching vibrations of small water cluster (H2O) n (n = 2−10) in the gaseous state have been investigated using infrared depletion and fragment spectroscopy. The stretching vibrations are found to be size specific spreading over a wide range from 3720 to 2935 cm-1 with the higher nuclearity cluster showing the vibration below 3400 cm-1. In comparison, the O−H stretching vibration in ice appears24 at 3220 cm-1, while in liquid it shifts24 to 3280 and 3490 cm-1. Therefore, the O−H stretching frequency of the water cluster in 1 is more like ice with a slight variation attributable to its surroundings. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns of 1 before (simulated) and after water expulsion show a complete change in the pattern, suggesting breakdown of the host lattice due to the exclusion of water. This result is expected, as the water cluster acts as a “glue” to assemble the coordination polymeric chains around it, leading to the 3D structure.
elements.clean_text: Thermal gravimetric analysis on a 10.02 mg sample of 1 shows the onset of water loss at 50 °C. Water removal takes place without showing any distinct plateau in the curve, giving a total loss of 20.8% at ~150 °C corresponding to loss of free water molecules (calculated value, 19.2%). The complete decomposition of the compound is achieved above 180 °C. The FTIR spectrum of 1 shows a broad band centered around 3202 cm-1, which vanishes on heating the compound under vacuum at 140 °C for 2 h due to the escape of water from the lattice. Deliberate exposure to water vapor for 3 days does not lead to reabsorption of water into the lattice as monitored by FTIR spectroscopy. The O-H stretching vibrations of small water cluster (H2O) n  (n = 2-10) in the gaseous state have been investigated using infrared depletion and fragment spectroscopy. The stretching vibrations are found to be size specific spreading over a wide range from 3720 to 2935 cm-1 with the higher nuclearity cluster showing the vibration below 3400 cm-1. In comparison, the O-H stretching vibration in ice appears24 at 3220 cm-1, while in liquid it shifts24 to 3280 and 3490 cm-1. Therefore, the O-H stretching frequency of the water cluster in 1 is more like ice with a slight variation attributable to its surroundings. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns of 1 before (simulated) and after water expulsion show a complete change in the pattern, suggesting breakdown of the host lattice due to the exclusion of water. This result is expected, as the water cluster acts as a "glue" to assemble the coordination polymeric chains around it, leading to the 3D structure.

elements.content: In summary, we have observed an unprecedented 2D supramolecular water layer containing (H2O)18 morphology via a template in a 3D supramolecular framework. The water layers here take the role of sheets, and 1D coordination polymer chains act as pillars in forming the 3D supramolecular network. As water molecules play an important role in contributing to conformation, stability, function, and dynamics of biomacromolecules, the new 2D water layer may provide insight into the hydrogen-bonding motif of the aqueous environment in living systems and enhance understanding of the 2D structural aspects of water.
elements.clean_text: In summary, we have observed an unprecedented 2D supramolecular water layer containing (H2O)18 morphology via a template in a 3D supramolecular framework. The water layers here take the role of sheets, and 1D coordination polymer chains act as pillars in forming the 3D supramolecular network. As water molecules play an important role in contributing to conformation, stability, function, and dynamics of biomacromolecules, the new 2D water layer may provide insight into the hydrogen-bonding motif of the  aqueous environment in living systems and enhance understanding of the 2D structural aspects of water.

cln_elements.content: Thermal gravimetric analysis on a 10.02 mg sample of 1 shows the onset of water loss at 50 °C. Water removal takes place without showing any distinct plateau in the curve, giving a total loss of 20.8% at ∼150 °C corresponding to loss of free water molecules (calculated value, 19.2%). The complete decomposition of the compound is achieved above 180 °C. The FTIR spectrum of 1 shows a broad band centered around 3202 cm-1, which vanishes on heating the compound under vacuum at 140 °C for 2 h due to the escape of water from the lattice. Deliberate exposure to water vapor for 3 days does not lead to reabsorption of water into the lattice as monitored by FTIR spectroscopy. The O−H stretching vibrations of small water cluster (H2O) n (n = 2−10) in the gaseous state have been investigated using infrared depletion and fragment spectroscopy. The stretching vibrations are found to be size specific spreading over a wide range from 3720 to 2935 cm-1 with the higher nuclearity cluster showing the vibration below 3400 cm-1. In comparison, the O−H stretching vibration in ice appears24 at 3220 cm-1, while in liquid it shifts24 to 3280 and 3490 cm-1. Therefore, the O−H stretching frequency of the water cluster in 1 is more like ice with a slight variation attributable to its surroundings. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns of 1 before (simulated) and after water expulsion show a complete change in the pattern, suggesting breakdown of the host lattice due to the exclusion of water. This result is expected, as the water cluster acts as a “glue” to assemble the coordination polymeric chains around it, leading to the 3D structure.

The complete decomposition of the compound is achieved above 180 °C. The FTIR spectrum of 1 shows a broad band centered around 3202 cm-1, which vanishes on heating the compound under vacuum at 140 °C for 2 h due to the escape of water from the lattice. Deliberate exposure to water vapor for 3 days does not lead to reabsorption of water into the lattice as monitored by FTIR spectroscopy. The O-H stretching vibrations of small water cluster (H2O) n  (n = 2-10) in the gaseous state have been investigated using infrared depletion and fragment spectroscopy. The stretching vibrations are found to be size specific spreading over a wide range from 3720 to 2935 cm-1 with the higher nuclearity cluster showing the vibration below 3400 cm-1. In comparison, the O-H stretching vibration in ice appears24 at 3220 cm-1, while in liquid it shifts24 to 3280 and 3490 cm-1. Therefore, the O-H stretching frequency of the water cluster in 1 is more like ice with a slight variation attributable to its surroundings. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns of 1 before (simulated) and after water expulsion show a complete change in the pattern, suggesting breakdown of the host lattice due to the exclusion of water. This result is expected, as the water cluster acts as a "glue" to assemble the coordination polymeric chains around it, leading to the 3D structure.

metadata.title:
Formation of Two-Dimensional Supramolecular Water Layer Containing (H2O)18
Morphology via Dianion Templating
